Posts.Content: Hi Jane, What a crap time you have been having. You have every right to feel angry. I tootled along in denial, this had everyone saying how positive I was being!!! Good for you for going to get counceling. Making that decision is the first step towards getting to grips with everything. I hope it all works out soon for you and wish you the very best. with love,
Posts.Title: Anger

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, Just a note to send you our love and best wishes. Hope the follow-up is'nt so painful both physically and mentally. big hugs, Debbiexxx
Posts.Title: Anger

Posts.Content: Ho Lesley, I am so sad to read that your friend lost her fight. I hope you continually take comfort from your new friends here. Sending you lots of hugs. LOL as well, Debbie and April xxxx
Posts.Title: losing the fight

Posts.Content: Ho Lesley, I am so sad to read that your friend lost her fight. I hope you continually take comfort from your new friends here. Sending you lots of hugs. LOL as well, Debbie and April xxxx
Posts.Title: losing the fight

Posts.Content: hi sandra, best wishes with the chemo, keep us posted, LOL Debbie
Posts.Title: Stomach churnings

Posts.Content: Hi Sandra, Sorry to hear thay have stopped you just when you were getting past the first few hurdles. I had a very mild attack of stomach churning, they put me on Zoton fast tabs, the same thing you would get for very bad indigestion. I'm surprised thay have not found something for you. If it is your chemo causing it then are they talking about a different chemo. Not all drugs suit all people. I lost a stone within a week then it stopped there. So hopefully you wont loose any more. I wish you all the best, LOL Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Stomach churnings

Posts.Content: Hi Girls, I am going in for my recon next week, 8th may, a back flap and implant. I have just heard that i am going to be getting the other one reduced at the same time. I do hope they match as no one will be able to tell until i stand up!! What ever we have done is always going to feel odd as so much invasive work has taken place. All I know is that I cant look any odder than i do now. At least i hope not. I will report back after the op with I hope the good news. Very best wishes to you both, LOL Debbie xxxx
Posts.Title: Implants

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona, I did'nt have a cancerous lump, but a breast peppered with cancer and it was Oestregon receptive. I was on HRT so got regular periods and before that my periods had stopped so stopped as soon as I came off the HRT. Not very helpful really. Our bodies are so different and act differently. I hope you are getting on well. Lots of love,
Posts.Title: Before a breast lumps was discovered did your periods cease

Posts.Content: You certainly came to the right place to have your worries put at ease. I had my Mastectomy in 2005. Never had any pain from the start. I done as I was told. Went a bit mad with the exercises cos no body explained them to me properly so just went into them full on. But that was good, cos when I went to a physcio for a check up she was amazed that I had so much movement after only 3 weeks. I also had cording after t he operation but that did'nt bother me and it vanished after about 4 months. This year I decided to go for a reconstruction. Had a few unimportant probs with it (crease in the implant, so it had to come out) so going back in feb to have it all finished off. Still no pain with any of that. The one thing I can say, is that I was fit before I went into my op. and as it was over 2 months from diagnosis to op, I made an extra effort to get as fit as poss so that the six weeks recuperation would'nt leave me to floppy. I did not do anything after the operation that was a no no, as I wanted to be back to work 6 weeks to the day. I wish you all the very best with your op and recuperation. Keep intouch and let us know how it is going. lol and (((((HUGS))))) Debbie and Robbie xxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: mastectomy - can it be pain-free in the long term?

Posts.Content: Hi there caroline, I agree with the brave bit, gets my goat up. We wake up one morning and find we have cancer and have no choice but to cope in what ever way we can. Anyway, FEC, I was on that for 6 x 3 weeks. Not a prob for me. I lost my hair after 2nd dose. Decided to shave it off when it began to come loose. I was given a goodie bag to go home with which had anti sick pills, steroids (for 24 hour anti sick) and mouth wash as you can be subject to mouth ulcers. They forgot to give me my goodie bag on the second and third time, and I thought maybe you only got it first time so said nothing. Well, as I was ok after those treatments I didnt bother with the steroids at all. The chemo used to make me feel heavy headed so I came home and went to bed. Stayed there for 24 hours then took a day to get back on my feet, then back to work. I was sick, just once each time and always about 8pm so it became all part of the routine. Sometimes if your white cells have not got back to full strength then you have to wait an extra week before you can have your chemo. One of the drugs in the FEC cocktail, burns in private places but just for a second or two and they do warn you. I was advised to eat before chemo because if it did make me sick, better to have something in my tum. Before, during and after chemo I made sure I kept as healthy as pos and ate plenty of fruit and veg. I assume a portacath is so you dont have to have needles stuck in you each time, if so that is really good, makes it so much easier. I could'nt have anything like that as i work with horses and could not be sure to keep it clean. Ooooh, ive rather gone on a bit. hope its of help. Ask more if you want Best wishes for a smooth ride through chemo, LOL Debbie and April xxxx
Posts.Title: Advice

Posts.Content: Dear Sharon, Only just caught up with your thread. I hope as time has passed you have got on ok with the prognosis and treatments that have been selected for you. Just like everyone else, You could be writing my diary of 3 years ago. Until i found this site in march, i thought i was the only one with those thoughts. I am so glad you have found us because you will get more comfort and support than you could imagine from the wonderful people on here. I wish you all the very best, LOL Debbie and April xxxx
Posts.Title: New to the club.

Posts.Content: Hi Sandy, The other place worth checking out are the charity shops. Especially if like me u cant sew a button!! I found some lovely ones even a couple of designer labels. Also for those cold nights and when in doors and not wanting to wear a scarf all the time I highly recommend Muslim prayer caps, obtainable from the internet. If you are good with a needle you can sew pretty sequins or motifs on them. I hated the "chemo scarves". I have a very little head and they just looked awful on me. Best of luck
Posts.Title: Headscarves!

Posts.Content: Hi Jane-Ann, Sounds a bit like you have "cording" in your arm pit. I took pics of mine and sent them to the Ameona life people (can be googled) they done an article about cording, I think it was july 07. They put the pic in the mag. This is (i think where the ligaments or tendon goes into a spasm) and go taught thus leaving a "rope like" sinue sticking out across the armpit. I had this after my op, it slowly went over a few months I think. Not sure how long it was, but just noticed one day that it had gone. As for the numbness, that sometimes goes sometimes stays. All depends on the nerve damage/repair. The whole of my arm was numb but now (3 years on) only part of the armpit is numb. no more shaving with a bic as too risky. Now have to use an electric razor. got a really nice narrow one in Argos, v cheap called Remmington lady shave. The head is only half inch wide. I hope we have all managed to give you some idea and you feel better about the whole situation. You can always talk to the help line on here they are great. I wish you all the very best with any further treatment. Lol Debbie and April
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Its all sounding good for you, I'm very pleased. Look after yourself and Do keep intouch. Lol Debbie and April xxxxx
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Hi, Just a foot note, my friend had 26 removed and all positive. That was 10 years ago. She is in fine fettle and looks great. lol Debbie and April xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Your arm will get its use back, dont worry about that. The most important thing is getting through with the op and treatment. It is a very long hard journey but at the end you will look back and think "was that really me". As Kate says, they inject local and what with the interference with the nerves you prob wont have any pain. Be aware of the first time you touch your arm pit. It is very dead and feels like a lump of rubber. A most disconcerting feeling. But as with everything else you will get some feeling back in time and you also get used to the feelings. I would like to wish you all the very best with your ops and treatments. Keep us informed how you are getting on when you feel up to it. lol and ((((((((((((((((((HUGS)))))))))))))))) Debbie and April xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Hi Carole, You can google the chillo . They are called chillo personal cooling systems. Best wishes with the rest of your treatment and have a fantastic holiday. lol Debbie and April xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Well done to both carole and Jane-ann. I am so pleased that you are nearing the end of your treatments and are sounding so upbeat about it all. Its not silly to worry about anything else that pops into view with regard to our bodies. After getting that initial diagnosis I will never let anything go unchecked. Dont care if i irritate the docs. It's our bodies and there is only us to keep a check on it, and keep it fit and well. I will also raise a glass to you both at the end of the week. It's so nice to be able to celebrate something for a change. lol and hugs to you both, Debbie and April xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Hi Jane Ann, I was carrying a "water bottle" around on my back, infact it turned out to 300ml. my surgeon said that it is the bodies own way of protecting the raw areas from each other. A bit like a blister. If you dont pop it, when the skin has healed underneath then it begins to reabsorb the fluid. I dont know if this is the same as armpit and arm fluid retention. But hopefully it will go down with time. I have great faith in my onc and if she had said leave it i would have. So how do you feel about yours. You can also ask on the help line on here. There advice is totally impartial. I am glad to hear that your team at maidstone were good and supportive. You could also call your macmillan nurse. The exercises do get easier and before you know it, you will be back to doing all the things you are used to with that arm. I wish you all the very best. lol n hugs Debbie and April xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for your lovely e-mail. Please don't apologise for not replying. I didn't expect a reply. You are the one that is having to deal with impact which a cancer diagnosis brings. I am pleased that my words bought you some comfortl I am so pleased to read your upbeat sounding words (oh what bad English). There will be days when you drop down but with your attitude you will pick up again. Remember we are always near by when you need an understanding ear to bash. And we are definitely interested in how things are coming along. So whenever you feel up to the task of updating your blog, there will be plenty of us ready to catch up. I wish you all the very best with your appointments and treatments. lol and ((((((((((((((((Hugs)))))))))))))))))))0 Debbie and Robbie xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Steamrollered - Whats the rush!

Posts.Content: I Cant believe what i have just read. That is just terrible. To be put through any bad news breaks up your whole world. But to be told that all the secondary could have been avoided if a proper diagnosis had been given in the first place, just adds to the hell that you are all going through. This is happening just too often, it really must stop. We are constantly hearing how consultants and oncologists are just not interested in or giving time to their patients, and as i do understand they are rushed off their feet, never the less every patient deserves the very best attention to detail, and if you cant rely and trust on them then where the bliddy hell can you turn? Sorry, I've gone on to rant mode. I wish your dad every success. Although this will not undo what has gone before, hopefully it will highlight yet again that this sort of thing is not acceptable and maybe help prevent it happening to someone else. My love and hugs go out to you and your family. Debbie and Aprilxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx((((((((((((((HUGS)))))))))))))
Posts.Title: I don't believe it!
